trial_identification.studytitle: Treating spider phobia using Neuro Emotional Technqiue (N.E.T.): A pilot study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial using Neuro Emotional Technique (N.E.T.) compared to no intervention for treating adults aged 18 to 65 years with spider phobia as measured by the Subjective Units of Distress Scale (SUDS)

interventions.interventions: Neuro Emotional Technique (NET) is a relatively new stress-reduction technique whose aim is to remove neurological abnormalities which have a specified physiopathological pattern. Oftentimes emotional trauma can cause a learned emotional response, a conditioned fear, and as a result, a related physiopathological pattern. Under normal conditions, the learned response becomes extinct, and the physiopathological pattern resolves. However, occasionally this does not happen, and both persist. This especially seems to be case in phobia. The goal of NET is to normalise these aberrant patterns through a physical correction. It involves the dynamics of memory, muscle testing, and some principles of Traditional Chinese Medicine (i.e. the meridian-emotion relationship). The experimental group received two 30-minute sessions of NET - once per week for 2 weeks.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Mean change in Subjective Units of Distress Scale (SUDS) scores
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At initial and final assessments (approximately 2 weeks later)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Mean change in Spider Questionnarie (SPQ) scores
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At initial and final assessments (approximately 2 weeks later)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Mean change in Becks Anxiety Inventory (BAI) scores
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At initial and final assessments (approximately 2 weeks later)
At initial and final assessments (approximately 2 weeks later)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Mean change in Behavioural Assessment Test (BAT) scores
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At initial and final assessments (approximately 2 weeks later)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Self-reported spider phobia; fluent in English
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Currently being treated for spider phobia; Currently have another disgnosed mental health condition

trial_design.concealment: Enrolment was via flyers, posters and general email between January and June 2007; group allocation was via sealed opaque envelope chosen by the participant following their initial assessment.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Department of Social Policy and Social Work Barnett House, 32 Wellington Square, Oxford OX1 2ER, UK

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This trial's aim was to test the efficacy of using Neuro Emotional Technique (NET) to reduce the severity of the symptoms of spider phobia in adults. It was hypothesised that NET would reduce the severity of both subjective and objective symptoms of spider phobics
